awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Revitalizing Rural - Equipping Rural Communities with Technology Literacy for Seizing Productivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Lack of participation in the digital economy is an impediment to societal well-being and production which asymmetrically affects rural communities. The literature indicates that technological availability (e.g., broadband) is only a part of the problem: rural communities are not as active as their urban counterparts in technology adoption. The adoption problem covers the extent to which rural communities have the financial resources and awareness, skills, and aspirations (or collectively, the literacy) to seize the productivity opportunities afforded by smart and connected technologies (SCT). This planning project will conduct a pilot study to determine how improved technology literacy can impact the rural adoption of SCT for building productivity to economically and socially revitalize rural communities. Specifically, this project will explore the development of a novel educational tool for technology literacy called Productivity Enhancing Technology Experience-Kits (Pete-Kits). Pete-Kits will be combinations of low-cost devices such as microprocessors and sensors that make use of communications technologies like WiFi, Bluetooth, and Radio Frequency ID (RFID), and which can be combined with cloud connectivity to support high school students as they develop entrepreneurial SCT projects within their rural communities. These kits will be developed with input from high school students and community members. High school teachers and students will receive training on how to use the kits, and students will then be invited to develop their own SCT entrepreneurial projects which will be judged in a final community competition event.

The research will examine: (1) how rural awareness of SCT is influenced by hands-on experiences with Pete-Kits, (2) to what degree are the basic skills for using SCT increased through interactions with Pete-Kit, and (3) the effects are of Pete-Kit based training and competition on rural participants’ productivity, and their aspirations for entrepreneurship, remote work, and quality of life within their community. These questions will largely be addressed via survey instruments, administered both before and after the intervention, to both participants and to attendees of community events. Community forums and workshops will also be held to review the strengths and weaknesses of the Pete-Kit program, and to develop relationships with other communities and tribal nations for future scalability. This planning project aligns well with the Smart & Connected Communities program’s goal to accelerate the creation of the scientific and engineering foundations that will enable smart and connected communities to bring about new levels of economic opportunity and growth. This project is also receiving funding from the ITEST program, which has priorities for (1) increasing awareness of STEM & ICT occupations, (2) motivating students to pursue educational pathways to those occupations, and (3) developing disciplinary content knowledge and skills necessary for entering those occupations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in numerous and continuing outcomes aligned with the intellectual merit and broader impacts originally proposed.  We review the fundamental motivation that lack of participation in the digital and technology-based economy is an ongoing challenge that is particularly impactful in rural communities.  Nevertheless, rural communities may have the most to gain by incorporating smart and connected technologies into their lives, in terms of both economy and well-being.  Furthermore, such technologies could enhance rural productivity, thus bolstering the sustainability of these communities.  We hypothesized that a technology training curriculum based on novel electronic educational tools and entrepreneurship training could raise technology awareness, skills, and ambitions within rural communities.  Our project centered around training using a “PETE-Kit,” which stands for Productivity Enhancing Technology Experience.  This pilot project was designed to gauge the effectiveness of such training and discover important research questions to help us better understand its impact and unknowns.

The broader impacts of the project have been a strong success.  For one, the project supported one Ph.D. student and one undergraduate researcher (a Native American), who both received valuable research training from the work.  Second, the work was very successful in advancing public scientific literacy and engagement.  The community with which we collaborated was highly engaged in the research and maintained a strong interest in the project from start to finish.  This was manifest by excellent turnout and discussions during our community events, strong and sustained enthusiasm for the community well-being and its link to the technological and entrepreneurial training provided during our project, and the shared investment realized between the community and the students of Frederick High School (our trainees).  Third, we involved outreach and participation with several external partners from industry, academia, and governmental agencies, including Amazon, Northern Oklahoma College, the United States Air Force, and nearby rural municipalities, all of whom expressed an interest in rural sustainability and encouraging the flow of rural students into STEM careers.  Fourth and finally, we presented a training curriculum that our rural partners recognized as empowering to their community and its well-being.  The unique combination of technology and entrepreneurial training was widely regarded as both optimistic and important for realizing the full potential of rural youth and their participation in both the rural community and the digital economy, simultaneously.

In terms of intellectual merit, the project has resulted in both fundamental and practical research advancements.  We set out to: 1) determine the extent of awareness of smart and connected technologies among those in a rural population, 2) determine whether the skills to use smart and connected technology can be conveyed to that population in a fun, hands-on way, 3) determine whether technology literacy, coupled with entrepreneurial training, could enhance the ability and willingness of rural citizens to engage in entrepreneurship or remote work, and 4) determine whether our curriculum was scalable to a much wider population.  We were pleased to find meaningful results in all four categories.  Some notable examples are that we found school teachers and students have mostly commensurate levels of technology literacy, and that both can be significantly improved, whereas the community was more enthusiastic than teachers toward the application of the training.  We found that the PETE-Kit was effective at training certain elements of technology, and even more effective at raising the awareness of available technology to trainees.  Importantly, we found entrepreneurship training, in partnership with technology training was a key advantage in our endeavor.  Both the community and trainees (the students of Frederick High School) found the entrepreneurial element of the project fun, informative, and highly relevant to their community goals.  Finally, we learned the strengths and weaknesses of our curriculum and several questions that need additional research.  Fortunately, we also found that this program is easily scalable to a wider population.
